title-group.article-title: Effect of sheet-metal thickness and hardness on the life cycle and sliding force of a novel ultraslim spring unit for a semi-automatic sliding mechanism used in IT devices

abstract.p: Great strides made in the industries manufacturing components for IT devices have facilitated the development of cellular phones that are either similar in size or smaller than previously existing phones. In addition, the functions carried out by devices such as MP3 players, digital cameras, and GPS devices are now being incorporated into cellular phone, the quintessential IT device. However, there are limitations on the extent to which the sizes of the components can be reduced due to technical reasons pertaining to mechanical and/or electrical properties, the manufacturing process, and the structure of the assembly. In addition, more emphasis than ever is being placed on the design of a cellular phone as it has come to be regarded as a necessity; thus, like an accessory, it needs to be stylish, highly mobile, and portable, regardless of advances in technology. To develop phones that meet these requirements, the thickness and degree of design freedom have to be reduced and improved, respectively. With this in mind, we propose a novel spring unit for the slide mechanism of a cellular phone as a practical alternative not only for maintaining the mobility and portability of the phone, but also for increasing competitiveness as this component helps to reduce the thickness of the phone. In addition, it provides a degree of freedom that allows other hardware components in the phone to be placed and adjusted more freely than conventional spring units built for the same purpose. Experiments conducted indicate that the life cycles and sliding forces of our proposed spring can be easily set by merely controlling the thickness and hardness of the sheet metal plate used for fabricating the spring. Furthermore, our proposed spring can be used to further reduce the thickness of the existing IT devices while preserving their performance and reliability. We believe that our etching process using heat-treated sheet metal can be widely applied to fabricate springs for various applications that require minimized thickness.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent times, portable IT devices such as mobile phones, MP3 players, digital cameras, and GPS devices have become necessities in modern society. There has also been a gradual incorporation of the functionalities of devices such as MP3 players and digital cameras into modern mobile phones. Consequently, mobile phones have become so popular that sales volume has reached one billion units.1 To grab a larger share of this vibrant market, major mobile phone manufactures are therefore expending every effort to increase the competitiveness of their products by improving their designs and adding more supplementary functionalities.

Research studies on the design of mobile phones have been conducted with the aim of harmonizing performance and mobility. These studies focus on various aspects of mobile phones such as design based on the axiomatic approach,2,3 customization to reflect the needs of customers,4 and a methodology for analyzing individual differences using human sensibility ergonomics called Kansei Engineering.5,6 In addition, studies to minimize and optimize the size of components,7–11 and to protect them from shock,12 have been carried out.

The studies mentioned above focused on reducing the overall size of the end product – which itself depends on various design parameters including the thickness of the case and components such as printed circuit boards (PCBs), integrated circuits, and processors. The components must be small in order to make the product more competitive. However, there commonly are limitations on how much reduction in thickness can be achieved. These limitations include technical reasons related to the surface mounting technology of the PCB, the material used for the case, the manufacturing process, the structure of the assembly, and the slow pace at which other technologies are developed.

The slider type mobile phone is popular around the world due to the fact that its display size can be maximized to enable using the phone as a touch phone, and it enjoys most of the merits of both the bar type and the folder type mobile phones. In particular, the use of a semi-automatic sliding mechanism in this type of phone can, in the future, facilitate the addition of a QWERTY type of keypad in smartphones – thereby solving problems such as the inconvenience experienced when entering data using conventional small phone keypads.

As a result of these perceived advantages, research and development into the construction of a semi-automatic sliding mechanism has been carried out in order to reduce the overall thickness of the product, as it is not possible to further reduce the space occupied by the existing components of a mobile phone using the existing technology. Under these technical limitations, improving the technology associated with the spring is considered the best way to further reduce the size of the phone. In fact, new design mechanisms have been proposed.

Of particular note is the spring in sliding mechanism based on the above-mentioned axiomatic design3 proposed by Hwang and Han.13 Studies on reliability improvement14 and the stiffness15 of the spring in the sliding mechanism for practical usage were also performed. In addition, a variety of spring units and hinges with better specifications have been developed. However, the results of tests on these mechanisms are currently closed to the public.

In the aforementioned studies associated with the sliding mechanism, the existing tension, compression, and spiral (or torsion) springs were kinematically combined to produce various kinds of slide hinge units. However, multiple springs are generally required in order to obtain sufficient sliding force in the finished product. The use of multiple springs reduces the amount of space available for the deflection of a flexible printed circuit board (FPCB) in the same assembly space. This reduced space serves to diminish the degree of freedom of PCB artwork related to the insertion of connectors located at both ends of the FPCB. Thus, a novel spring unit is essential to solving the problems discussed above as the spring affects the design, hardware specification, and size of the handset.

Few papers or reports have been published on how to remove the existing demerits – such as short life cycle, high rate of decrease of the sliding force, which is proportional to the amount of use of the mechanism, and high cost – associated with the semi-automatic sliding mechanism. In our study, a novel spring mechanism made from general-purpose sheet metal was manufactured using an etching process. Springs were fabricated in various thicknesses and hardnesses from the sheet metal and then tested to ascertain their feasibility in terms of life cycle, sliding force, and the relationship between sliding force and durability of the product.

sec.title: The sheet metal spring concept
sec.p:
Figure 1 depicts our analysis of the development trends and comparisons of the spring units in IT devices. As can be seen in Figure 1(a), first generation spring units have torsion or spiral springs coiled over two layers. These units are very reliable due to the load distribution by the two springs and the relatively long wire rod length. In addition, open and close sensibility is smooth. However, a minimum of two springs are required for the reliability and the slide force suitable for the mobile phone. Furthermore, this type of spring unit is relatively thick due to the fact that forming and heat treatment after forming bring about deformation in the thickness direction, and the spring has a two-layer structure without the supporting body to prevent deflection to the vertical of the end product. As a result, more driving space in the width and thickness direction is required for the sliding mechanism. Second generation units have compression springs waved with a one-layer structure by the spring forming machine. This type of spring enables the device to be thinner, as the thickness of the spring is less than that of first generation springs. However, as is the case with the first generation units, two springs are required, and the deformation caused by coiling and heat treatment after coiling can disrupt the flatness of the unit. Consequently, it is thinner than the first generation slide hinge, but their drive regions are similar. Third generation units are called push-rod units. They have multiple compression or tension coiling springs. The springs are arranged in a row or in rows. In this generation, the springs combine or link with the body to form a novel slide hinge. This unit is easy to assemble in the end product and is dimensionally stable because any spring whose degree of flatness is affected by the forming and heat treatment is realigned by the body or link. Therefore, deformation in the direction of thickness is minimized. However, it is easy for dust to become trapped between the spring and the body due to its closed structure, and the material worsens in sensitivity in proportion to the number of times it opens and closes. In addition, the lifespan of the unit is heavily dependent on the environment in which it is used. We call our novel spring mechanism the ‘flat spring unit’ and, as shown in Figure 1, regard it as a fourth generation unit. This spring is fabricated by means of etching on a sheet metal plate. The hardness of the plate is controlled by the heat treatment condition, and as expected, the controlled plate indicates the different spring forces. In particular, because the spring is fabricated by an etching process, its formability does not depend on the hardness of the material, the roundness of the tool used, or chemical reaction. However, the maximum thickness of the plate with the cutting plane without burr is limited to within 1.0 mm, and the relevant technologies can be required for a more powerful spring force. Figure 1(b) compares existing recent spring units with our product for IT devices. As can be seen in the figure, our unit is superior to all other units, even though those other units (the existing spring units) have already been commercialized. Figure 1.
Development trend and comparison of spring units for IT devices: (a) comparison with early spring units and our products for IT devices and (b) comparison with recent spring units and our products for IT devices.

Figure 2 shows a selection of conceptual flat springs manufactured by the etching process. As is evident from Figure 2, arbitrarily shaped flat springs can easily be manufactured via the etching process. In addition, it can be inferred springs that are impossible to produce via existing conventional methods due to their sharp edges and rapid change in shape can be realized without springback. A flat spring has a rectangular cross-section due to the forming process and cross-section of the plate. This rectangular cross-section is more advantageous than a circular one in terms of the spring force and flatness. This is attributable to the following reason. Figure 2.
Various flat springs: (a) concept design of flat spring and (b) various samples manufactured using the etching process.

The deflection of a horizontally curved member such as a flat spring is governed by equation (1), which is the same as that for existing springs (1)δ=πFR32EI where F, R, E, and I designate applied force, radius of centroidal axis, Young’s modulus, and second moment of area, respectively. Since ‘I’ is determined from the cross-section of the spring, the moment of a spring with a rectangular cross-section is as follows (2)Ix=bh312
(3)Iy=b3h12 where b is the width in x-coordinate and h the height in x-coordinate. If the spring has a circular cross-section, the equation is as follows (4)I=43r4 where r is the radius of the wire. If the length of a side is equal to 2r, the diameter of the circular cross-section, then b is equal to both h and 2r, and thus, equations (2) and (3) become (5)I=π4r4

The deflection associated with the cross-section is converted using equations (4) and (5) as follows: (6)δ(Rect)≈πFR32E×1r4×34
(7)δ(Circ)≈πFR32E×1r4×3π

On comparing equations (6) and (7), it can be seen that the deflection of a spring with a rectangular cross-section is less than that of a spring with a circular cross-section. This shows that in the case of a spring with a rectangular cross-section, a larger force is required to deflect the spring. Therefore, it can be concluded that a spring that has a rectangular cross-section is more robust and less susceptible to bending than one that has a circular one.

In the case of a wire rod with a rectangular cross-section, if the short and long sides are b and h, respectively, the value of Ix is larger than that of Iy. This implies that the plane with the shorter side tends to bend first. Therefore, the flatness is maintained such that the plane with the longer side is perpendicular to the drive plane. For example, on comparing the cross-sections of wire rods with dimensions 0.4 × 0.6 mm2 and 0.4 × 0.9 mm2, the following result is obtained.
0.4 × 0.6 mm2 wire rod: from equations (1) to (3)
(8) I1x=bh312=0.4×0.6312=0.0072
(9) I1y=b3h12=0.43×0.612=0.0032
(10) F1x≈2EδπR3×0.0072
(11)F1y≈2EδπR3×0.0032

The force required for a change in Ix with the shorter side of the cross-section is 2.25 times greater than that required for Iy with the longer side of the cross-section. This fact shows that when the wire is bent by a load in an arbitrary direction, the deflection of the Iy axis, where I denotes the second inertial moment, is smaller than that of the Ix axis.
0.4 × 0.9 mm2 wire rod: from equation (1) to (3)
(12) I2x=bh312=0.4×0.9312=0.243
(13) I2y=b3h12=0.43×0.912=0.0048
(14) F2x≈2EδπR3×0.243
(15) F2y≈2EδπR3×0.048

For a 30% increase in the length of the longer side, the force required for a change in Ix with the shorter side of the cross-section is approximately three times greater than that required for Iy with the longer side of the cross-section. This behavior indicates that the spring force and the deflection in the thickness direction can be controlled. Therefore, because of the difference in the second inertial moment, no support is required to prevent the deflection in the thickness direction.

sec.title: Manufacturing of the novel spring unit
Materials for the experiment
sec.p:
For this study, a sheet metal of heat-treated SK5 steel was used as the material for fabricating the flat spring. The chemical composition of SK5 is given in Table 1. Generally, the hardness of raw SK5 – a carbon tool steel – is only 170 ± 10 HV. However, the mechanical properties of the material can be controlled relatively easily by varying the heat treatment conditions in a process called austempering. As a result, in this study, heat-treated SK5 plates with hardnesses 170, 300, and 400 HV and thicknesses 0.4, 0.5, and 0.6 mm were utilized, as indicated in Table 2. The common value of the cross-sectional width of the spring was 0.9 mm. Table 1.

sec.title: Design and fabrication of the flat spring
sec.p:
Figure 3 gives representative 2-D and 3-D drawing data for the flat spring. Figure 3(a) presents representative 2-D drawing data, for which a wave type of spring was proposed to effectively disperse the stress. It was designed for a 36-mm sliding stroke. However, an increase in the total length of the spring decreases the spring force. Therefore, the effects of hardness and thickness of the sheet metal on the spring force and the life cycle were investigated in order to verify the efficacy of the spring. Figure 3(b) depicts the 3-D drawing data. The spring is assembled at the counterparts by the holder parts of both ends. The dimensions of the holder parts are the same as those of commercial holder parts. It is also customizable. The material of the holder is polyoxymethylene (POM), also called polyacetal, a lubricating plastic. The holder is manufactured separately and can be combined with both ends of the spring by an insert injection molding process or thermal bonding at both the ends. In this study, the holders were assembled by thermal bonding. The spring was manufactured via an etching machine. Figure 3.
2-D and 3-D drawing data for flat spring and equipment: (a) 2-D drawing data for flat spring (0.5 mm) and (b) 3-D schematic drawing data.

sec.title: Manufacturing
sec.p:
Figure 4 depicts an etched plate with multiple flat springs. As can be seen in the figure, the offset area around the outer line of each spring has been removed, except for two supporting parts called the bridge. These two parts prevent the lightweight spring hanging from the plate from being removed by the external force generated by the circulation of the etching solution in the etching machine. On the other hand, no bridges are formed in the deformed region because of the short life cycle of the stress concentration on the spring and the fact that no defects such as notches occur during the cutting process. As a result, just two bridges can prevent each spring from being deflected. Thus, the flatness of the spring is the same as that of a sheet metal plate that has a flatness of 0.03. Considering that the flatness of existing springs is between 0.1 and 0.15, this flat spring is amazingly flat. Its very low flatness value prevents the spring from being caved over or abruptly collapsing during the process of repetitive deformation. This result indicates that no supporting body for the spring is required, and both the thickness of the unit and drive space is reduced. In addition, the hardness and thickness of the plate had no effect on the formability. Figure 4.
Etched sheet metal plate.

Figure 5 shows the flat spring separated from the sheet metal plate. The bridges of the spring shown in Figure 5(a) were simply cut using a nipper as they have no influence on the life cycle nor are they external parts. If the exterior portion and productivity are significant, any problem that may arise from inaccurate cutting can be minimized using an automated cutting jig. The holders for the spring shown in Figure 5(b) were easily bonded by thermal bonding using a soldering iron. The degree of precision of dimensions can be improved by using the insert injection molding process to form the holder in cases where the spring has to be inserted into a vertical die. Figure 5.
Completed flat spring units: (a) ejected spring and (b) spring with holders.

Figure 6 gives a comparison of the predicted cross-section of a flat spring for the case of an incomplete etching process. Figure 6(a) shows the spring sample manufactured for such a case. Though the problem depicted in Figure 6(b) was not discovered in this instance, in cases of incomplete etching, the cross-section shown in Figure 6(b) could result from the etching process. In this state, the strength of the spring increases; however, its durability decreases because of self-contact in the spring. Figure 6(c) shows the expected cross-section of a spring manufactured by a press that can fabricate springs with a similar shape. Swelling effects are characteristic of the press process related to springback of the spring and the lifespan of the press die. If the hardness of the sheet metal plate is high, i.e. over 400 HV, it is impossible to fabricate the spring via this press process. In the press process, a variety of parameters – such as punching speed, tool sharpness, and holding force – must be controlled. As a result, we believe the etching process to be more suitable than the press process for manufacturing springs. Figure 6.
Cross-section of the flat spring: (a) spring sample; (b) a–a cross-section (etching); and (c) a–a cross section (press).

sec.title: Experimental condition
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows the sliding mechanism of a cellular phone that utilizes our spring. As illustrated in the figure, if during the sliding process the sliding part moves more than half of the stroke (y), semi-automatic sliding is activated by the force of restitution accumulated due to the compressive force. Unless the distance moved is less than half of the stroke, the sliding part resiles from the present position to its original one. In addition, the initial force of the spring holds the phone in the open or closed state, preventing the phone from dangling, and the mechanism from malfunctioning, when the phone is being carried and not in use. In IT devices such as the cellular phone, the flat spring is repetitively compressed and restored by the pin connection with an assembly condition of 23 mm (x-axis) and 30 mm (y-axis), respectively. The springs fabricated for this study were deformed by a distance between 23 and 30 mm. A life-cycle test is essential because repetitive deformation can give rise to fatigue failure. In addition, it is necessary to evaluate the sliding force because the test is performed under conditions existing during practical use. Therefore, the effectiveness was verified to check whether the mechanical performance obtained satisfied the requirements listed in Table 3. Figure 7.

Figure 8 shows the equipment used for the life-cycle test and the mock-up of various tests. As illustrated in Figure 8(a), four cellular phones can be simultaneously tested. Two independent controllers are installed, and the test can be performed under two different conditions. The maximum testing speed is 80 strokes/min, but in this study, the testing speed used was 30 strokes/min, which is the general testing speed in tests performed by mobile set manufacturers. The number of strokes can also be periodically controlled to examine the test results. In the life-cycle test, the transparent mock-up made from acrylic (shown in Figure 8(b)) was checked frequently for internal problems such as abrasions, spring deformation, and dust penetration. The material of the holder was the lubricating plastic POM. Figure 8.
General-purpose life-cycle testing for mobile phones: (a) life-cycle testing machine and (b) mock-up (maximum compression).

sec.title: Mechanical performance
sec.p:
Table 4 shows the results obtained under the conditions listed in Table 2. The life cycle is inversely proportional to the thickness of the sheet metal. In addition, despite the same thickness, the span is inversely proportional to the hardness. Because thickened spring and increased hardness prevent deformation, the sliding force is increased. Therefore, we concluded that the enhanced stress loaded at the spring has a strong effect on the life cycle. Table 4.
Hardness and life cycle of the flat spring.
Thickness (mm) Hardness (HV)/average life cycle (kilo cycle, ±15 k)
0.4 170/no limit 300/252 400/220
0.5 170/193 300/152 400/95
0.6 170/72 300/62 400/45

The sliding force was measured using a machine called the semi-automatic push–pull gage stand. The measurement was automatically performed, and the measuring speed and stroke were easily controlled and repetitively estimated. The measurement results were displayed using Z-Link software for the push–pull gage made by the IMADA corporation. To examine the sliding force in a stroke, five measurements were carried out per stroke.

Table 5 shows the spring forces produced under the various conditions listed in Table 2. As listed in Table 5, the spring force is proportional to both the thickness and hardness of the plate. However, the increase in the sliding force decreases the lifespan because of the increase in the stress accumulated in the spring and in the size of the fibrous tissue of the heat-treated plate, which is proportional to the hardness. From the results shown in Tables 3 to 5, we concluded that the most appropriate spring unit for IT devices such as a cellular phone with a 36-mm stroke (used in this study) was the one with a thickness of 0.5 mm, hardness of 300 HV, and spring force of 236 gf. If an increase in the sliding force or a decrease in the thickness of the end product is required, the design can be optimized accordingly by taking the above-mentioned results into consideration.

Figure 9 graphically depicts the spring force in the sliding stroke. The flat spring used in this study was made of SK5 steel and had a thickness of 0.5 mm, hardness of 300 HV, and stroke of 36 mm (‘Experimental condition’ and ‘Mechanical performance’). As shown in Figure 9, the spring was assembled with a preload, and a rapid change in the sliding force was encountered during the sliding stroke between 16 and 20 mm. This rapid change occurred because semi-automatic sliding was activated – the moving holder of the unit passed over the midpoint of the total stroke, called the dead point, which is the position at which no resiling occurs, and it continued moving in spite of the removal of the external force. In fact, a dead region, not just a dead point, exists because of the frictional force between the counterparts. Therefore, not only the maximum sliding force, but also the position of the dead region must be evaluated because the frictional force increases the sliding force and changes the location of the dead region. Figure 9.
Sliding force versus the sliding stroke.

Figure 10 graphically depicts the sliding force versus the number of instances of open and close. The sliding force decreases in proportion to the number of instances of open and close. For this reason, the sliding force after 100,000 cycles required in the IT industry is over 70% of the initial force. However, in the case of our hinge, the sliding force after 100,000 cycles was approximately 90% of the initial force, which greatly exceeds the corresponding requirement listed in Table 3. Figure 10.
Sliding force versus the number of instances of sliding.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, the following results were obtained from the study of a flat spring fabricated from a sheet metal plate for use in a semi-automatic sliding mechanism used in IT devices:
A flat spring that has a rectangular cross-section is better at resisting deflection than a spring that has a circular cross-section.
The flatness of the flat spring manufactured by the etching process is the same as that of the sheet metal plate, and no support is needed to prevent the spring from caving over.
The sliding force is proportional to the thickness and hardness of the sheet metal plate; however, it is inversely proportional to the life cycle. Of various springs that we fabricated under different conditions, we found flat spring with a thickness of 0.5 mm, hardness of 300 HV, and width of 0.9 mm to be the most appropriate for use in the semi-automatic sliding mechanism of IT devices.
The hardness of the heat-treated plate is proportional to the sliding force, but increasing the size of the fibrous tissue due to the heat treatment decreases its life cycle.
From the reliability testing results, our sliding force after 100,000 cycles was more than 90% of the initial one, which far exceeds the existing specification of 70%.
